summary.seg: This manuscript mainly comprises two large theological works. The first is a copy of William of Auvergne's De sacramentis, which, according to a colophon, was copied by the scribe Thomas Singulton of Newark in 1442. In the published version of his 1999 Lyell Lectures, Malcolm Parkes grouped Singulton together with other examples of commercial scribes who signed their copies, and suggested that the inclusion of place names in such inscriptions advertised to a manuscript's reader, and prospective future customer, where a scribe's services could be found.

To Singulton's work was later added, but not much later, a second theological text: a previously unidentified mid- or late 15th-century collection of excerpts from the Memoriale presbyterorum, an early 14th-century manual for parish priests that is known in only five other manuscripts. An additional quire of eight leaves was used to accommodate the Memoriale. The blank page (f. 78v) in between the end of De sacramentis and the beginning of the Memoriale was filled by the copyist of the latter text with more than a dozen Latin aphorisms, including one attributed to St Ambrose: 'Sputum hominis ieiuni est venenum serpenti' - 'The saliva of a young man is the poison of the serpent'. This is found in Ambrose's Hexameron, but was widely quoted, including among the Sermones of Jacobus de Voragine.

The manuscript retains its medieval endleaves, which were recycled from a 14th-century account roll. Entries therein reference York and Lowthorpe, which suggests that the book spent part of its life in the north-east of England. An inscription in the margin of f. 83v records the gift of the book by an unnamed legator to a 'William Cat', chaplain, 'in order that he say a trental for my soul after my death'. A trental is a set of thirty requiem masses. The chaplain named may have been the William Catte who was made rector of All Saints' Church, Edingthorpe, Norfolk, in 1465.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: A parchment manuscript (theology) with three flyleaves taken from another manuscript (account book).

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
f. [i] and [ii] are modern paper flyleaves; ff. 1-2, and 86 are original parchment flyleaves; f. [a] is a paper pastedown on the f. inside of the lower cover and is not included in Extent.

note.p: Quire numbers written in pencil in Arabic numerals 1-10 in the lower right-hand corner of the recto side of the first leaf of each quire (to mark the beginning of the quire), added in the 19th century.
Collation formula written in pencil on f. [ii] verso, by the hand of H.L. PinkPink, H. L..
Crosses written in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the recto side of the first leaf in the second half of the quire (to mark the centre of the quire), added in the 20th century.

binding.p: Quarter binding of light brown sheep leather with grey marbled paper sides over mill boards, old paper shelf mark labels pasted on a paper pastedown on the inside upper cover.
Rebound in August 1958 by Douglas Cockerell and Son, according to a note pasted on the inside cover ([a]) signed 'SMC' (i.e. Sydney Morris ('Sandy') CockerellCockerell, Sydney Morris.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 136 (f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum AngliÃ¦ et HiberniÃ¦ (c. 1697).

acquisition.p: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the front pastedown.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose (Woodbridge: Brewer, 2009), pp. 26-30; and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: Latin Bookhands of the Later Middle Ages, 1100-1500
Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts c. 737-1600 in Cambridge Libraries
Their Hands Before Our Eyes: A Closer Look at Scribes: The Lyell Lectures Delivered in the University of Oxford, 1999
Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo)

analytic.title: "Thys ys my boke": Imagining the Owner in the Book

monogr.title: Spaces for Reading in Later Medieval England

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Hh.6.13, ff. 1r-2v, 86r-86v

msItem.title: Household accounts [I]
msItem.note: Accounts of a monastery or other religious institution with a list of food and drink distributed to the poor, with several references to Boceham and Woddekok.

msItem.title: Household accounts [II]
msItem.note: Bound upside down. Accounts of a monastery or other religious institution with a list of food and drink distributed to the poor, including a reference to York: 'new wine bought near York' (vini noui empt. apud Ebor.); and payments to Henry Barton (Henrici Barton), John of Sadyngton (Et solucium Johannis de Sadyngton pro diuersis [...]), Lowthorpe in the East Riding of Yorkshire (louthorp pro parte expens. clericorum existencium oxonie), and Richard Wardroper (Et solicium Ricardo Wardroper pro iij [...]).

extent.seg: Fragments, comprising leaves taken from a roll.

supportDesc.condition: Leaves are heavily stained, with damage to ff. 1-2 that may have been caused by rodents.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in Anglicana script.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Hh.6.13, ff. 3r-85v

msContents.textLang: Theological texts written in Latin, with added medical recipes in Middle English

msItem.title: Table of contents
msItem.rubric: 3r Ad cognicioenem operis [...]onem fac[...] in eo continentur est notandum quod [...] sunt capita signata et littere signate: unde qui uult inuenire aliquem casum in aliquo sacramento contentum querat per tabulam sequentem primo capitulum et postea litteram
msItem.incipit: 3r Quod baptismus est ianua omnium sacramentorum
msItem.explicit: 8r Quod exorcismi ad illud amouendum non ualeant

msItem.title: De sacramentis
msItem.author: William of Auvergne
msItem.rubric: 8r Conclusiones sacramentorum descriptis fratris thome de alquino et aliorum doctorum extracte
msItem.incipit: 8r Quoniam me sepius rogasti petre postquam sacerdocij sacrum ordinem suscepisti
msItem.explicit: 77r et de iura recurre pro tum in hoc opere pro te fesso ipsum exores quo omnia sacramenta uirtutem obtinent dominum uidelicet ihesum Christum qui cum patre et spiritu sancto viuit et regnat deus benedictus in secula seculorum Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 77r Secundum manum Thome Syngultoun scriptoris de newerke. In anno domini nullio CCCCo quadragesimo secundo
msItem.note: Written in the form of a dialogue between Silo and Petrus

listBibl.bibl: Parkes, Their Hands Before Our Eyes (2008), p. 45 n. 83.

msItem.title: Medical recipes for leg and foot injuries
msItem.textLang: Latin recipes with Middle English headers
msItem.incipit: 77r For a sowr leg Ã¾at ys red and halys nyght and dey
msItem.explicit: 77r oyl do lefh and blake sowp for Ã¾e sa[me]
msItem.note: Added in the second half of the 15th century.

listBibl.bibl: Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo) (2009), p. 204

msItem.title: Latin aphorisms
msItem.incipit: 77v Quid enim prodest corpus attenuare abstinencia: cum anima
msItem.explicit: 77v Sparne voluptates nocet empta doloro voluptas
msItem.note: Written in or after 1442 by the same scribe who copied ff. 78r-85v.

msItem.title: Memoriale Presbiterorum (Collection of excerpts)
msItem.incipit: 78r Sic penitencia [erased: presbiteri] fornicantis Si [erased: presbiteris] fornicacionem fecerit debet penitere per x. annos
msItem.rubric: 79r Pro quibus culpis et penitencijs sit penitens ad episcopum remittendus
msItem.incipit: 79r Pro quibus culpis et penitenciis sit penitens ad episcopum proprium remittendus
msItem.explicit: 85v contra illos prestans eadem pena vel paulo minore punire
msItem.note:
A previously unidentified collection of excerpts from the Memoriale Presbiterorum, an early 14th-century confession manual for parish priests that has been identified in five manuscripts:
Cambridge, University Library, MS Mm.5.33
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 148
London, British Library, MS Harley 3120
London, Westminster Diocesan Archives, MS H.38
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Selden Supra 39 .
A comparison with the earliest surviving copy - Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 148 - shows that the collection here contains twelve of its chapters in the following order: A.49, A.45-47, A.101, A.103, A.104, A.96, A.41, A.60-62.

listBibl.bibl: Michael J. Harren, Sin and Society in Fourteenth-Century England: A Study of the Memoriale Presbiterum (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2000) [without this manuscript]

signatures.p: A single leaf signature ('f.i') in the lower outer corner of f. 42r.
Three medieval quire signatures on ff. 49v, 57v, 65v ('f', 'g', 'h').

supportDesc.condition: The vellum is in good condition though dirty and stained in places, particularly at the beginning and end where leaves are slightly cockled.

layout.p:
ff. 3r-77r: 150 100
Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 29-30 lines to the page. Written below top line.

ff. 77v-85v: 150-155 100
Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 27-31 lines to the page. Written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 3r-77r are written by a single hand in a Northern Textualis.
ff. 77v-85v are written by a single hand in a cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Two- and one-line plain red initials on ff. 3r-77r.
Linefillers in red ink throughout ff. 3r-85v.
Cadels in brown ink on ascenders of words on first lines on ff. 40v-77r.
One-line littera notabiliores highlighted in red throughout ff. 3r-85v.
Paraphs in red ink throughout ff. 3r-77r.
Cardinal numbers in lists in frames of red ink on ff. 79r-83r.

note.p: A note in Latin on pregnancy in the lower margin of f. 83v in a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand, relating to the text's discussion of adultery: Hoc stereare [sic: ? scelerare] est pellis in qua pue in ventre matris.

A note in Latin on sandals in the lower margin of f. 16r in a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand, probably responding to the text's discussion of liturgical clothing: Sandalia dicuntur sotilares episcopales vel sotilares reges.
Note of payments for sheep (yones iiijs [...] rames is iiiiijs shep iiiiij), added to the upper margin of f. 34v in the 16th century.

Notes in Latin in the outer margin of f. 13r in a late 16th- or early 17th-century hand relating to the text's description of the sacrament of the Baptism, beginning: Utrum puer non baptizatus cum matre, and modus baptismi.

A note in English in the lower margin of f. 19v in a late 16th- or early 17th-century hand relating to the text's description of the sacrament of the Eucharist: Ye maie reioyce to receyve this sacrament as a man reioceth when he hath gotten his princes seale.

origin.p: The first main text (ff. 3r-77r) ends with a scribal colophon that dates the text to 1442: 'Secundum manum Thome Syngulton' scriptoris de newerke. In anno domini millesimo quatrocentesimo quadragesimo secundo [1442]'. To this were added texts (ff. 77v-85v) by a 15th-century hand.

provenance.p: Donation inscription in the lower margin of f. 83v: lego istum librum Wyllelmo cat capellano ut ipse dicat unum trentale pro anima mea post mortem meam. The legator is not named, however the chaplain to whom he left this book may be the William CatteCatte, William who was made rector of All Saints' Church, Edingthorpe, Norfolk, in 1465 (see Francis Blomefield and Charles Parkin, An Essay towards a Topographical History of the County of Norfolk [...] Collected out of Ledger-Books, Registers, Records, Evidences, Deeds, Court-Rolls, and Other Authentick Memorials, 11 (London: Printed by William Bulmer for William Miller), p. 29).

Richard Sacwell Sacwell, Richard: his name ('Rychard Sacwell') inscribed in a late 16th-century script in the outer margin of f. 58r, and perhaps his first name ('Rysha[rd]') inscribed in the same hand on f. 29r.
John SandlandSandland, John: his name ('John Sandland') inscribed in a late 16th-century script in the outer margin of f. 58r.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
